lesson.title: Personal Finance Management
lesson.description: This lesson focuses on understanding money management, the difference between wants and needs, and strategies for self-reliance in personal finances.
objectives: Know the difference between debit and credit
Identify strategies for staying out of debt
Set a realistic short term personal finance goal

activities.title: Wants and Needs
activities.content:
In the wise words of Mr. Eugene Krabs from *Spongebob*, "Counting me money. Money sweeter than honey. Money money this, money money that. Profit will make me wallet fat!"

We live in a society that relies heavily on <def def='A type of money used in a particular location, such as dollars in the United States and pesos in Mexico.'>currency</def> to operate. This lesson focuses on finance topics and may cover topics you are already familiar with, as well as some you may not know as much about; these topics will prepare you for being <def def="The ability to take care of one's own responsibilities and self rather than relying on others">self-reliant</def> as you personally manage your finances.

To begin, let's think about the difference between wants and needs when it comes to finances.

activities.title: Understanding Income
activities.content:
When you have a job, you earn money. That money is called <def def='Money you earn from working or other sources.'>income</def>. The amount of income you earn is not always the amount of money you get to keep. Income is divided into <def def='The full amount of income you earn.'>gross income</def> and <def def='The amount of income you keep after taxes and other costs are taken out.'>net income</def>.

<def def='Gross income is the full amount of your earnings. Depending on your job, this income could be determined by a set annual amount of earnings not changed by hours or days worked (salary), earnings that correspond with the number of hours or days worked (wages), or earnings that are dependent on completing a specific task, such as selling an item (commission).'>Gross income</def> could come from your <def def='A set annual amount of earnings, not changed by hours or days worked.'>salary</def>, your <def def='Earnings that correspond with the number of hours or days worked.'>wages</def>, or your <def def='Earnings that are dependent on completing a specific task, such as selling an item.'>commission</def>.

<def def='Net income is the amount of earnings you get to keep after deductions have been made.'>Net income</def> is a part of your gross income, and is the amount of earnings that you get to keep after <def def='Amounts of money taken away for specific purposes, such as taxes or insurance.'>deductions</def> have been made. Some common deductions include money taken out for state and federal taxes, healthcare, retirement plans, and insurance.

For each paycheck, you will receive a pay stub that details information regarding your pay rate, income, deductions, and other information. This will include information for the current pay period, and may also include totals of these amounts from the calendar year. This is sometimes abbreviated as "YTD," meaning "Year to Date."

activities.title: Understanding Taxes
activities.content:
An important part of having a job and living independently is being prepared for <def def='Money that people and businesses pay to the government to fund services like schools, roads, and emergency response.'>taxes</def>. Taxes are money that people and businesses pay to the government. They help pay for things that everyone uses, like schools, roads, parks, and emergency services.

When you earn money from a job, a portion of your paycheck usually goes to taxes before you even see it. The amount depends on how much you earn and the tax rules where you live. You may also pay taxes when you buy things, like clothes or food, because sales tax is added at the register.

When you are hired by an employer, you will fill out a <def def='A form you complete when starting a job that tells your employer how much tax to withhold from your paycheck.'>W-4 form</def>. This will give your employer the information they need to provide you with a <def def='A form you receive each January showing how much money you earned and how much tax you paid during the previous year.'>W-2 document</def> each January that includes information about your income and taxes you have paid so that you can file your taxes. If you work multiple jobs in a year, you will receive more than one W-2 and will use all of them when filing your taxes.

If you work a <def def='Working for yourself rather than for an employer, often for short-term or part-time jobs.'>freelance job</def> (example: nanny, yardwork) you may not fill out a W-4 form and will not receive a W-2. In this case, you are responsible for keeping track of your own income and paying taxes on that income.

activities.title: Filing Taxes
activities.content:
Filing taxes is the process of telling the government how much money you earned in a year and making sure you paid the right amount of taxes. Most people do this once a year by filling out a tax return, either online or on paper. If too much money was taken out of your paycheck, you might get a refund. If not enough was taken out, you may need to pay the difference. Filing on time helps you avoid problems later and makes sure you get any money back that's owed to you.

When you file taxes, you have a few options:

* **File online:** There are many companies that provide guidance on filing taxes by yourself through an online service, such as H\&R Block or TurboTax. The IRS itself has began offering this service for free in some situations. These services help you know what to fill out and catch errors as you go. This option can be free or can cost a small fee and is the easiest way to file taxes on your own.   
* **File with a tax preparer:** There are many companies and certified tax preparers who can help you with your forms and submitting your taxes. This option may cost a bit of money but is a great option for individuals who own their own business or have complicated tax situations.  
* **File manually by yourself:** for this option you complete a 1040 and other documents and submit them online or by mail to the IRS. This option is free but leaves more room for error and is not recommended for beginners.

activities.title: Reading a 1040 Form
activities.instructions:
This document is a 1040 and is what you fill out to submit your individual taxes to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Each year, you will need to file taxes between January (when you receive all W2 forms) and April 15th.

Take some time to become familiar with the document. If you file your taxes online, you will go step by step and will not see the whole document at one time.

As you look through the 1040, look for the total income from the W-2 form and the amount of taxes owed. You will need to click on the 1040 in those two places and answer the multiple choice questions to continue.
activities.feedback: Nice work identifying the total income and amount owed! Understanding these forms helps you know how much you've paid and whether you'll owe or get a refund next time you file.

activities.title: Types of Pay
activities.instructions: Not everyone earns money the same way--there are different types of pay depending on the job. Some people are paid wages, which means they earn money for each hour they work. Others receive a salary, getting a fixed amount each pay period no matter how many hours they work. Then there's commission, where people earn money based on how much they sell or produce. Understanding how your pay works helps you know what to expect on payday--and how to plan for what's next. Watch the video to hear some examples of different types of pay different jobs use.

activities.title: Debit, Credit, and Budgeting
activities.instructions: Click through the slides to learn about checking accounts, debit, credit, and building a good credit score.

slides.content: After you get paid, your money has to go somewhere--and there are a couple of ways that can happen. Some people get their paycheck through direct deposit, which means the money goes straight into their bank account. Others get a paper paycheck they can take to a bank or cash at a check-cashing place.
It's a good idea to have a checking account, which helps you keep your money safe and makes it easy to pay for things using a debit card.

Now let's talk about debit. A debit is money taken out of your bank account to pay for something. When you use a debit card, the money comes out right away. It's money you already earned. If you don't keep track of how much you spend, you might run out before your next paycheck--and that can cause problems like <def def='a banking fee that occurs if you spend more money than you have available'>overdraft fees</def> or missed payments.
Tip: Always know how much money is coming in and how much is going out. That's how you stay in control of your money.

Some people use credit cards to pay for things instead of using money they already have. When you use a credit card, you're borrowing money from a bank or company--and you promise to pay it back later.

Unlike debit cards, the money doesn't come out of your account right away. But if you don't pay it back on time, you can be charged <def def='extra money charged when borrowing money or earned when saving money'>interest</def>, which means you'll owe even more than you spent.
Most credit cards come with a credit limit, which is the maximum amount you're allowed to borrow. If you go over that amount, your card might be declined or you might get charged extra fees.
To get a credit card, you usually need to apply through a bank or credit union, and they'll check things like your income or credit history to decide if you qualify.

Using credit can help you build a credit score, which shows how good you are at paying back money. A good credit score can help you in the future if you want to rent an apartment, buy a car, or even get some jobs. But using credit the wrong way--like spending more than you can pay back--can hurt your score and make it harder to borrow money later.

A credit score is usually a number between 300 and 850--the higher the number, the better. A score of 670 or higher is generally considered good and can help you get approved for loans, credit cards, and lower interest rates.
Tip: Only use credit when you know you can pay it back--and try to pay off the full amount each month. That way, you avoid extra fees and build a strong credit history.

activities.title: Laticia's Story
activities.instructions: **Read or listen to the story to learn about Laticia's experience with debt. As you take in the story, consider what Laticia could have done differently and what you might do to avoid debt.**

slides.content: When I turned 18, getting a credit card felt like unlocking a new level of freedom. I was finally an adult, and having that little piece of plastic made me feel like I had real buying power. At first, I used it for small things--lunch with friends, a new pair of shoes, gas here and there. But pretty quickly, I started using it for things I couldn't really afford: designer bags, weekend trips, birthday gifts, even covering rent when my paycheck came up short. I kept telling myself it was okay, that I'd catch up soon, that I'd get a better job or make a big payment once I had extra money. But that "extra money" never came.

By the time I was 20, I had maxed out not just one but two credit cards. I was making only the minimum payments, and it felt like I was just throwing money into a hole. Every month, the <def def='Extra money charged when borrowing money or earned when saving money.'>interest</def> made my balance grow, even when I didn't use the cards. Most months, the interest charge was more than my minimum payment. I started getting calls and emails from the credit card companies when I missed payments. I ignored them at first, but eventually, I couldn't avoid it anymore. I was stressed all the time, and I didn't want to check my bank account or look at my credit report.

Now, I'm in a spot where I really need a car. I got a steady job offer, but I can't rely on rides forever, and the bus schedule doesn't line up with my shifts. I tried applying for an auto loan, but the lender told me my credit score was too low and that I'd need a big down payment to even be considered. I don't have that kind of cash. That was a wake-up call. I always thought I had time to fix things later, but now I'm realizing that the choices I made when I first got that credit card are still following me. I wish I had understood more back then about how credit really works. Now, I've got some work to do to get out of debt and rebuild my score so I can move forward.

activities.title: Types of Debt
activities.instructions: Read the infographic to learn more about debt.
activities.content: Debt can be helpful or harmful, depending on how it's used. Good debt is usually tied to something that grows in value or supports your future--like student loans for education or a car loan to get to work. Bad debt often comes from borrowing for things you don't need or can't afford, especially if the interest rates are high, like with credit cards or payday loans. This infographic breaks down common types of debt and highlights key things to consider.

activities.title: Developing Savings
activities.instructions: Read about how savings accounts work and how they can help you prepare for expenses and grow your money over time.
activities.content:
One way to be prepared for debt, unexpected expenses, and larger purchases is by developing savings. In addition to checking and credit accounts, you can open savings accounts with your bank. Savings accounts do not come with a debit or credit card, but instead are there to hold money that you would like to try to avoid spending--at least for now. Like credit accounts, savings accounts typically gain <def def='Extra money charged when borrowing money or earned when saving money.'>interest</def> but unlike credit, this interest is not a charge to your account. Instead it is additional money that the bank gives to your account as a benefit to keeping money saved with them. Although this interest is typically a small amount, it can add up over time and make a difference.

It's a good idea to save a bit of money from every paycheck you receive and avoid taking money out of your savings account as much as you can. Interest gained on savings depends on how much money is in your account already so the more you save, the more you will gain!

Some banks also have programs to help you save money as you spend money. For example, you may have the option to automatically <def def="Moving money from one place to another, like sending money from your checking account to your savings account, or from your bank to someone else's bank.">transfer</def> money from your checking account to your savings account every time you make a <def def='Any action that changes the money in your account--like a deposit, withdrawal, transfer, or a purchase with your debit card.'>transaction</def>.

activities.title: Things to Save Money For
activities.instructions: Watch the video about saving money or read the transcript. As you do, consider what you will prioritize when saving money.
activities._TODO: add transcript to video?:
**Transcript:**

**Emergency funds:** It's a good idea to prepare for emergencies or unexpected costs by putting money into savings. Experts usually recommend a 3-6 month emergency fund that is equal to your expenses for that time. That way, if something happens like losing your job, you are prepared financially while you look for something new.

**Large purchases:** If you are planning on making large purchases, such as buying furniture, electronics, or appliances, it's a good idea to set aside money for at least a few months in preparation. The amount you save will probably depend on how much the item costs, but it's a good rule to wait to buy something until you can afford to buy it twice without going into debt. With purchases like this, you may want to use your credit card and then pay off your credit card with your savings in the next month--this can help build your credit.

**Events and travel:** Special events in your own life, like a wedding or having a baby, are certainly things that you should prepare for by saving money. Events such as these often have many unexpected costs or may be more expensive than expected. Vacations and travel also require some planning and are something you should prepare for financially in advance. Don't forget that with each of these, you will likely be taking time off of work, which may mean that not only are you spending more money, but you are also making less money than you typically would.

**Down payments:** A down payment is money that is needed when you take out a loan for a large purchase, like with a car or a house. This is money you will put toward the purchase right away before you receive the loan. A down payment should be around 10% of the cost, but the more you are able to put down, the better. Putting down more money will mean a lower monthly payment and possibly a better interest rate.

activities.title: Understanding Budgets
activities.content: A budget is a plan for how you use your money. By learning how to budget, you can cover your needs, save for future goals, and still enjoy some wants. There are different ways to budget, and this infographic will show you what a budget is, why it matters, how to make one, and strategies you can try to find the method that works best for you.

activities.title: Setting a Personal Finance Goal
activities.instructions:
At this point, you've learned the basics of personal finance, have developed some skills, and have learned about budgeting. It's time to set a finance-related goal to help you prepare for your future.

Even if you don't have a job or money right now, you can still practice building habits that will help you later. A goal doesn't always have to be about a number -- it can be about the steps you take and the way you think about money. These steps prepare you for when you do have income.

Here are some examples of financial goals you could set, even if you don't have money right now:

- "I will keep track of things I would spend on if I had cash, and notice which ones are needs vs. wants."
- "I will practice planning how I would use $20 in three different ways."
- "I will spend 10 minutes a week practicing how to fill out a budget sheet."
- "I will talk to a trusted adult about one financial question I have."

Think about a habit or practice you can work on now that connects to personal finance.
Example: "I will write down three money choices I might face after release and how I would handle them."

Once you have identified a habit or practice, turn that practice into a process goal you can try each week.
Example: "I will practice making a weekly budget plan, even without money, so I'm ready when I have income."
